instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dying on startup
threads.message:
Some light corrosion in different areas. <CAPACITOR>C6452</CAPACITOR> area, replaced all effected caps and resistors and checked around in diode for any stray shorts, also corrosion at <CAPACITOR>C5101</CAPACITOR> area replaced all effected along with J5100.
L8504 exploded and carbonized, replaced.  
A spot of damage at the LCD end of the J8500 connector, normally I would think this brain dead but as far as I can tell by the way the damage looks the short was between just pin 2 and 44, is it safe to assume <CHIP>U5250</CHIP> would take the hit and not the CPU?
When plugged in it climbs up to 19.9V .72 amps and I get .88V on <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_SW1</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_SW2</SIGNAL> briefly, then it goes down to 20v .01amp and it loses power.
Is this a dead CPU. Any idea what to look at first here?

[ATTACH type="full" width="60%"]57055._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dying on startup
threads.message:
CPU EDP (Embedded Display Port) lines are directly connected to J8500.
There is no protection against spikes from backlight output, in case of liquid spill.
So dead CPU...
